sentences.english: A certain old man told this tale; Uskahutchas was his name.
Once upon a time there was a man called Red-Stone;
sentences.footnote: KR: {asiniy-kâ-mihkosit} is a hyphenated in Bloomfield's text.

sentences.original: nama wîhkâc wâpahtam nôtinitôwin, osâm ê-sâkihikot ohtâwiyah aw ôskinîkiw.
sentences.text: nama wîhkâc wâpahtam nôtinitôwin osâm ê-sâkihikot ôhtâwiya awa oskinîkiw
sentences.english: never had he seen fighting, for his father too much cherished this young man.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê kîkisêpâ êh-picihk awah oskinîkiw kâ-kitimâkêyimikot ôhtâwiyah êwakôw - kaskitêsiyiwah; masinasoyiwah; êyakonih otinêw êh-têhtapit otêmah, êh-mîhkawikiyit.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê kîkisêpâ ê-picihk awa oskinîkiw kâ-kitimâkêyimikot ôhtâwiya êwako kaskitêsiyiwa masinasoyiwa êwakoni otinêw ê-têhtapit otêma ê-mîhkawikiyit
sentences.english: Then, one morning when the camp was being moved, this young man whose father loved him so, - a black brindled horse, that was the one he took and mounted, a fleet horse.

sentences.original: pôti êh-ayôwêpihk, wâhyaw êy-is-ôsêhcâyik, pêyak ayîsiyiniwah ê-sâkêwêyit êh-têhtapiyit, kotakah mina êh-têhtapiyit, êyâpic ômis îsi pimicipayiyiwa.
sentences.text: pôti ê-âywêpihk wâhyaw ê-isi-osêhcâyik pêyak ayîsiyiniwa ê-sâkêwêyit ê-têhtapiyit kotaka mîna ê-têhtapiyit êyâpic ômisi isi pimicipayiyiwa
sentences.english: Then, when the band halted, there from behind a distant ridge came a Blackfoot, mounted, and then another rider, and made across the country.
Then these others, the Assiniboine, made ready to fight.
Very many were the people who were coming to fight against them; and they fought.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê wâpamêw aw ôskinîkiw ôhtâwiyah kâ-kitimâkêyimikot;
sentences.text: kîtahtawê wâpamêw awa oskinîkiw ôhtâwiya kâ-kitimâkêyimikot
sentences.english: Presently the young man whose father loved him, looked upon them;
he watched his people fighting.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê kâ-wâpamât ôwîcêwâkanah êh-môskîstâmiht, nêwo kâ-nôtinâyicik êh-nâpêhkâsôwit, pikw îtah êy-isi-môskîscikêyit.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê kâ-wâpamât owîcêwâkana ê-môskîstâmiht nêwo kâ-nôtinâyici ê-nâpêhkâsoyit piko ita ê-isi-môskîscikêyit
sentences.english: Soon he saw his comrades being attacked, four of them fighting a brave who attacked  here, there, and everywhere.
sentences.footnote: CHECK kâ-nôtinâyicik - HCW unsure. probably conflation, ?sub{nôtinâyit}.

sentences.english: The plight of his companions angered him.
A white horse he rode who was slaying them.
Then he took his horse.
He mounted to join in the fight;
he held a lance and a knife, a broad knife.
He attacked the others here and there, as the thought struck him;

sentences.original: nipahêw ayîsiyiniwah, nêwo êh-nipahât, câpihcikanis ohci êh-tahkamât awah êkâ wîhkâc kâ-nôtinikêt oskinîkiw.
sentences.text: nipahêw ayîsiyiniwa nêwo ê-nipahât câpihcikanis ohci ê-tahkamât awa êkâ wîhkâc kâ-nôtinikêt oskinîkiw
sentences.english: he killed men, four of them, piercing them with his lance, that youth who had never fought.
As to the rider of the white horse who was so sorely besetting them,
“If he is brave, when I come to attack him, he too will come to attack me.
sentences.footnote: Probably an erroneous direction in one of these verbs.

sentences.english: If he is brave, he will dismount.
Then I shall kill him;
I shall stab him with this knife,” he thought.
They attacked each other.
When he got near, the other smiled at him.
He laughed at the other; he dismounted.
The other also dismounted.
They went for each other on foot.
The rider of the white horse held a tomahawk.
They came together.
The youth seized hold of the Blackfoot;
he held him by the arm and lifted it like this.
The other smiled at him.
“Now I shall kill him,” he thought, and stabbed the Blackfoot.
Like stone was the other, as he stabbed at him, and he did not pierce him.
When he stabbed at him again, the other smiled at him.

sentences.original: kîhtwâm omis ê-tôtahk, wâstinamâk, omis ê-tôtâkot, êkâ wiyah, êh-itikot;
sentences.text: kîhtwâm ômisi ê-tôtahk wâstinamâk ômisi ê-tôtâkot ê-itikot
sentences.english: When he did like this again, the other waved his hand at him, doing like this, telling him, “Do not!”
He gestured to him, telling him, “Take this lance.”
He took it.
The other pointed at the young man's horse; he took his horse.
They went from there, the other taking him along.
“I suppose it is that they are going to kill me,” he thought.
But he was not killed;
he was taken back; the Blackfoot took him home with them.

sentences.original: mistah ôkimâwiw, êh-itêyimikot êwak ôhci k-ôh-otiniht;
sentences.english: Because they thought of him, “He is a great chief,” was why he was taken;
he was not killed.
One winter he was away in the Blackfoot's country.
He was given that white horse.

sentences.original: êwak ôhci awa wâpastim tiyêhtapiyâni, niyôtinitohki, namoya nipikwahokawin;
sentences.english: “It is through this white horse, whenever I ride it in battle, that I am not wounded;
do not fear that you will be slain.
I give you this my horse.
It is of a magic nature;
by nothing at all will you be slain.
Go home.”
He returned home and went to see his father.
He saw that he was being mourned.
When he saw his father, greatly did his father rejoice that the youth was alive.
That is all.

sentences.original: namoya kayâs; mâskôc nôhtawiy ohtâwiyah êh-oskinîkiyit, êkospi mâskôc.
sentences.text: namôya kayâs mâskôc nôhtâwiy ôhtâwiya ê-oskinîkiyit êkospî mâskôc
sentences.english: It is not old; I suppose when my father's father was a young man, that, I suppose, is when it happened.
